title: Young-ja
text:
Young-ja, also spelled Yeong-ja, is a Korean feminine given name. According to South Korean government data, it was the most popular name for baby girls born in 1940. Its meaning depends on the <a href="hanja">hanja</a> used to write it.
Hanja and meaning.
There are 34 hanja with the reading "<a href="Young%20%28Korean%20name%29">young</a>" on the South Korean government's list of hanja which may be used in given names. The syllable "ja" is generally written using a hanja literally meaning "child" (; ). In Japan, where this character is read "ko", it was originally used as suffix for the names of girls in the aristocracy. The practice of adding "-ko" to girls' names spread to the lower classes following the 1868 <a href="Meiji%20Restoration">Meiji Restoration</a>. Names containing this character, such as <a href="Soon-ja">Soon-ja</a> and <a href="Jeong-ja">Jeong-ja</a>, became popular when <a href="Korea%20under%20Japanese%20rule">Korea was under Japanese rule</a> from 1910 to 1945, but declined in popularity afterwards. By 1950 there were no names ending in "ja" in the top ten. Some ways of writing the name Young-ja in hanja include:
